name: Andesite
texture: aphanitic to porphyritic (fine groundmass with feldspar/pyroxene phenocrysts)
diagnostics: fine overall; few visible quartz; often small white/gray phenocrysts

name: Basalt
diagnostics: very fine; heavy; may show vesicles; magnetite can make it weakly magnetic

name: Chert
diagnostics: conchoidal fracture; very hard (scratches glass); waxy/dull luster

name: Coal
diagnostics: lightweight; sooty streak; shiny to dull; burns

name: Conglomerate
diagnostics: rounded clasts >2 mm; clast-supported or matrix-supported

name: Gabbro
commonColors: dark gray to black with light flecks
diagnostics: coarse 'salt-and-pepper'; no visible quartz; heavy

name: Gneiss
diagnostics: distinct compositional bands; feldspar + quartz common

name: Granite
diagnostics: visible quartz (glassy, gray) and K-feldspar (often pink)

name: Hornfels
diagnostics: hard, dense 'ringing' stone; no foliation; baked appearance

name: Limestone
texture: micritic to fossiliferous; variable grain size
diagnostics: reacts vigorously with dilute HCl; fossils common

name: Marble
diagnostics: reacts with acid; crystals interlock; softer than quartzite
confusedWith: quartzite (very hard, no acid reaction), limestone (sedimentary textures)

name: Migmatite
texture: mixed: dark melanosomes + light, swirly leucosomes
diagnostics: irregular folded/swirled light bands cutting gneissic fabric

name: Mudstone
diagnostics: does NOT split into thin sheets; smooth feel

name: Phyllite
texture: fine; wavy foliation with silky sheen
diagnostics: satiny luster; minute mica give a sheen; faint wrinkling

name: Quartzite
diagnostics: scratches glass easily; breaks THROUGH grains; no acid reaction

name: Rhyolite
texture: aphanitic to porphyritic; may be flow-banded
diagnostics: light-colored volcanic rock; quartz not visible but felsic look

name: Sandstone
diagnostics: gritty feel; individual grains visible; often quartz-rich
confusedWith: siltstone (finer, slightly gritty), quartzite (metamorphic, very hard)

name: Shale
texture: very fine; fissile (splits into thin sheets)
diagnostics: breaks into paper-thin layers; smooth feel

name: Siltstone
texture: fine; slightly gritty (between sand and mud)
diagnostics: grittier than shale/mudstone; lacks sand-size sparkle

name: Slate
diagnostics: splits into flat durable sheets; dull luster; 'ping' when tapped
confusedWith: phyllite (silky sheen), shale (less hard, earthy break)

name: Travertine
texture: banded, porous; fibrous or concentric layers
diagnostics: calcite; strong acid reaction; visible pores/laminae

name: Tuff
texture: fragmental; ash matrix with pumice/lithic fragments
diagnostics: lightweight; may show shards/pumice; soft
